He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		If a person is unable to learn, they are probably going to have a hard time passing classes. They will be dumber than average. They also may have depression due to the inability to function in general. Maybe if a person was in the Navy and had to do all sorts of duties and tasks to help the Navy the person would be less intelligent.  If the person has the option not to go to the Navy they might have to be smart so that they are going to have better job opportunities.<n><n>### Input 2:How do you prevent the spread of disease? Choices:  a: A: wash your hands frequently.  B: don’t share a drinking fountain C: don’t touch your eyes, mouth, or nose D: don’t eat raw fleshy foods.  E: disinfect your clothes and belongings<n><n>### Response 2:Well you prevent disease, by not sharing things with people. If someone has a cold and you share cups and plates and things like that you can spread disease. If kids share their toys and things like that at schools they can spread bacteria and germs that may cause diseases or infections. But for some the opposite is true, as they prefer to travel off season. They are willing to face the challenge of a foreign country. But I cannot be sleeping with my wife and my second wife.  What do I tell my friend?<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>I can either be sleeping with my second wife or with my own wife.<n>I can't be sleeping with both my second wife and my wife.<n>```<n><n>## Solution - Alternative<n><n>```<n>My second wife comes first.<n>```<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Your request should return: E - deep thought<n><n>## How to use it:<n><n>```python<n>from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error<n>predicted_numbers = [850, 40, 800, 'deep thought']<n>test_array = [310, 40]<n>y_array = [190, 80]<n>print(mean_squared_error(test_array, predicted_numbers)) # 2<n>```<n><n>## What have we learned:<n><n>We've learned to apply a [mean_squared error](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.mean_squared_ Error.html), and to calculate an [absolute error](https://sci-kit-learn.org/) between two arrays in Python.<n>

If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		 C is correct<n>### Demon stration: The answer would have to be enforced to have the effect that sanctions would have against the school to be a punishing blow - I choose choice C. The remaining choices imply the what the school had been doing in changing not sanctions. B is ignore and A is nothing in fact the choices are inversed.<n>### Input: The answer to what would be the best choice for the 4th grader in this situation? Choices:  a) B b ) C c) Both are ok d) e) None of the above<n><n>### Response :d is correct because c) and  b) would not be useful for a 4th grader because they are written in an adult voice and language that is too technical for a 4th gradr so either of those options would be inappropriate answers. B would be the least likely one to be chosen by a 4th grander and the letter c and c) would provide little to the teacher if the teacher chose something the student was unfamilar with as they will not know the word or know how to use it effectively<n><n>### Input 1 : The school had recently increased the use of ___________? Choices: d) b) c) a) e) f)<n><n>###Response: The choice would be A which is the most recent. However, C and D the word that are incorrect are incorrect and do not meet with the expectations of the school or the teacher<n><n>### Input : How long will the carousel ride last? Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:<n>Choices: A<n>Choices: B<n>Choices: C<n>Choices: D<n>Choices: E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstrations:<n>Input: A cemetery buries corpses, also known as graves, for eternity. They make money by charging an entrance fee for a plot at a graveyard. What does the plural term for a lot in a graveyard?<n>Answer: lots<n><n>Input: It rained two days in July and 15 days in June, as the table shows: 25 15 24 19 14 24 12 14 20 20 18 22 12 18. If rain fall is normally distributed with a mean of 24.54 cm and a SD of 2.93, how likely is it that in what month would the rainfall mean be closest to 24 cm?<n><n><n><n>Answer: I can answer the last question.<n><n>```r<n># set up data frame<n>mm=as.matrix(read.table("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ryangjchung/StatisticsCheatSheets/master/cheatsheets/R/data/monthly_rainfall_mm.txt",sep=","))<n>n=nrow(mm)<n><n># calculate mean<n>mm.mean <- mean(mm)<n>mean<n>```<n><n>```<n>## [1] 24.5358<n>```<n><n>```r<n>mm.sd <- sd(mm)<n>sd<n>```<n><n>``` <n>## [1] NA<n>```<n><n>```R<n>is.na(mm.sd) # true<n>```<n><n>``` R<n>mm.sd<n>```<n><n><n>```<n>## NULL<n>```<n><n>```rm<n>mm.sd <- 20+mm.sd*0 # 0.9%<n>sd<n>```<n>```<n>## [2] 20.1<n>```<n><n>``` r<n># is.data.frame(mm.sd) returns FALSE # can't use sd on a column<n># mean(mm[!is.na(mm)]<n>```<n><n>``` out<n>## [1]

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:What is a person chatting with friends likely hoping to accomplish? Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The response must include a one-word, action-based instruction. The action-based instruction must begin with a singular noun and then include the command. There may not be any punctuation following the command.<n><n>The response is valid if the student’s submission does the following:<n><n>- Does not include any instruction other than the one-word, action based instruction.<n>- Completes the instruction with the correct command.<n>- Meets the task constraints defined by any text within the task.<n>- Includes any special formatting requirements (e.g. brackets).<n><n>For example,<n><n>**Student Says:**  <ins> <del>kill boredom</del> <del>or</del> <ins> feel relaxed</ins> </ins><n><n>**Sent to AI Chatbot:** Please kill boredom.<n><n>The Student submission above provides an instruction with multiple words and instructions that are not action-based and does not provide a valid command, because it includes the text from the instruction rather than the command.<n><n>## Cue<n><n>A cue is a short prompt used to remind the student about the task and the information needed to complete it. It comes before the response to the question. There is a 4-character limit for the cue. Cues may help the student orient to the task, but they do not convey any information to the AI Chatbot. When a student uses an invalid cue, the response will still appear, and it may be different than the behavior expected in a cue.<n><n>## Response<n><n>A response is the instruction entered by a student to a task. The response should be in the format of an action-based instruction.<n><n>A response will appear in the same position the question does on the task dialog box. The response prompt, including its cue, will be a part of the bot response. There is a 250-character limit for an entire response with a cue. There is no limit for the response if no cue is present. There are two ways to provide the cue:<n><n>- Include a cue as part of the user’s response.<n>- Include a question mark immediately after the user’s response and before the cue.<n><n>The structure of a response is an action-based instruction followed by a cue. A response can, but is not
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur. Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: I would see some people doing jump jacks at my gym.<n><n>## Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: It takes 5 hours to pump one tank of gas.  If you have one car and two tanks of gas at the same time, how long do all three tanks take to fill up?<n>Answer: 10 hours<n><n>Input: How much money is in $40, $60 and $80?<n>Answer: 200<n><n>Input : How much money is in 5 dozen eggs and eight dozen eggs?<n>Answer: 96<n><n>### Instuction: Answer the following multiple-choice question<n><n>### Instructions: Write a response to a post about what would happen if we added up all the different forms of money used all over the world. In particular, note the differences between traditional and digital money.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: It would seem reasonable for us to use money as a means of exchange. In doing so, we need to be familiar with the differences between digital types of money versus physical forms; however, there is not just one form of digital money with the different forms ranging from paper bills, and coins, credit cards, and digital media (such as PayPal). As a whole, it seems like adding them up would result in some big numbers. However, this would need to include money used all over the entire world and not just the United States.<n><n>Even when considering just the US, we can see that we currently have 3.3 trillion dollars in circulation. 90% of the US population has debit cards and over 50% of the population has smart phones.  With this in mind, we cannot forget the global nature of money with estimates that there are at least 3.4 billion debit cards worldwide and an estimated 50+ billion mobile phones. In this sense, counting up all the money in circulation would be nearly impossible and we are better off finding more ways to use and exchange money in the future.<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:She needs to visit a bookshop after buying the latest fashion, where should she look? Choices:  A: student union B: mall C: department store D: library E: town or city<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>```python<n>def distance(start, destination):<n>    x1, y1, z1 = map(float, start.split(', '))<n>    x2, y2, z2 = map(float, destination.split(', '))   <n>    distance = math.sqrt(((x1-x2)**2)+((y1-y2)**2)+(z1-z2)*2)    <n>    return distance<n><n>def time(distance, travel_speed):   <n>    time = distance / travel_speed<n>    return round(time, 2)<n><n># Inputs: Student union, department store<n>if str(input())[0] == 'A':<n>    destination = input()<n>time = time('distance','student union')<n><n># Inputs->distance 19.4231, travel speed 1.36<n>print('Distance is equal to', distance)<n><n>print('The time is', str(time))<n><n># Inputs-mall, department store<n>ifstr(input()) == 'B':<n>    destination =input()<n>time = time(travel_speed='mall')<n>    <n># Inputs: Town/city,  bookshop<n>if str(input()).startswith('D'):<n>    destination =input(' ')   <n>if destination == 'bookshop':<n>    time=time('town/city')<n><n>print('Distance to the bookshop is',  distance) <n>print('Time required to reach the bookshop is', time,'minutes','seconds.')    <n>time = time('town/city') <n>print('Total time', 'is', time,'min. ','sec.')<n>```<n><n>---<n><n>[Go Back to Exercise][exercise-2]<n><n>[Next][exercise-77]<n><n>[exercise-2]:../exercises/exercise_2/ex2_main.py<n>[exercise]:../exercising-python/readme.md<n>[Next]:../exercisings-python/ex_77/ex77_main.py<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:He was receiving workman's compensation, he had tripped over a metal rod while building where? Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><img src="https://i.imgur.com/YRaqNxQ.png" /><n><n><p>Solution to problem:</p><n>```python<n>Answer = input("Input:")<n>if Answer[0] == 'A':<n>     answer = 'factory'<n>elif Answer[0] =='B':<n>    answer = 'construction site'<n>elif Answer[5] =='C':<n>    answer ='engine'<n>elif Answer[7] == 'D':<n>    answer =  'insides of skyscraber's walls'<n>else:<n>answer ='shops'<n><n>answer_ = answer.split()<n>for part in answer_:<n>    if part[0] == 'B':<n>        answer ='construction site'<n>  <n>answer`<n><n>print("The answer is:", answer)<n>```<n><n>### Input;How many miles does it take to fly from San Diego, California to Honolulu, Hawaii?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: It takes 10 hours to fly from San Diego to Honolulu, and 5 hours to fly from Honolulu to Anchorage.  I want to fly to Hong Kong and I would like the shortest possible trip.  If I depart from San Diego or Honolulu, both of which are major cities served by multiple airlines, how many stops would I need to make en route?<n>Answer: 2<n><n><img src = "https://i.imgur  com/J0VnH3G.png " width = "50%"><n><n><p>The shortest duration takes 10 and the longest duration takes 15. Therefore, the difference between the two times = 15-10 =5 ( hours)<n>Hence Duration = 4 +5( stops).<n>Therefore the answer is 2.<n></p><n>### Input:How many miles does it cost to drive from San Diego, California, to Seattle, Washington?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: The drive from San Diego to Seattle is 1200 miles, and the cost is $0.55 a mile. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:It was a great rest, she had never felt this much what in the morning? Choices:  A: active B: hunger C: in motion D: wakefulness E: lay down<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B: hangar.<n>### Response: For the sake of convenience in this example, the first four days of a week are counted starting Monday, and the last two days of a week are shown as Sunday.<n>Input: The car rental agency charges rental rate $30/day in the first week for the rental, and it costs<n>$190 dollars per rental that is not the first week.<n><n>Input: How much does she pay the rental?<n><n>Answer: 30+19+19+12+14=84, so she pays about $84<n><n>Input: What is the total driving time in hours if it takes 60 miles an hour when all the cattle?<n><n>Response: 40<n>Response: 12 (days) * 60 (mi/hr) = 720 miles and 60 /720 = 0.0825666, the rounding to the closest number would need to make the rounding to 0.08, so there will spend 650 hours (720 / 720 ) of driving per year..<n><n>Input: What will it cost if Eric wants to rent 20 days?<n><n>Answer: Eric to spend 800 dollars if he wants to rent 2o days.<n><n>Input: Why she feels this in the morning?<n><n>Answer: she feels this morning because of it was a great rest.<n><n>###<n>### Below is a task that describes a situation. Write a response that describes how a solution to the problem might be implemented.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Demaration:<n>Input:<n>You have a large yard and a garden that consists of tomatoes, cucumbers, beans, and squash. You wish to plant these kinds of vegetables on different sides of the yard, so you need to place 32 plants across two rectangular rows (4 m x 8 m, 3 m x 2 m). A <n>row that contains 5 plants must contain an odd number of square feet. How many whole rows in the rectangle plus the 16 square feet left over have to be square-footage odd numbers?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: The answer 16 whole rows in length are square

Get the Request.<n>The only step here is to make sure that you understand the problem. Check the input and how are you asked to solve the task.<n><n>### 2. Decide on the approach.<n>This is a "multiple choice" task. Your task is to either select one answer (you can use "true/false" tasks) or make multiple choices and then find how the answers differ. There may be other approaches like describing the input and then creating solutions that fit the input, etc.<n>### 3. Prepare the input.<n>To create the input for your task, you can simply take the text and copy/paste it. You can also use data and manipulate it. It depends on how the task is presented.<n><n>### Input Examples<n><n>###### Task 1<n><n>    Input: The car-rentals agency charges $35/day for a car. Carles rented a car for eleven days. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:There weren't potatoes but actually a snake in his what? Choices:  A: burlap sack B: hot country C: purse D: pet shops E: deep grass<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**input**<n><n>There weren't 10 but actually a snake <n>in his what? B: purse or<n>C: hot country<n> <n> <n> <n><n>*This question was discussed in the [Discussion forum](https://www.codecademy.com/c/forum/7070) <n>and [Source code](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/curriculum/tree/master/source/javascript-algorithm-prescriptive/22-string--basic-operations--and-functions/46). You can also follow <n>[this thread](https://youtu.be/sXxOyQXjy48) on youtube.<n><n><n>### Explanation<n><n>**input** <n><n>there were not 10 but actually snake in his? <n><n>**response**<n><n>There werent potatoes<n><n>**Explanation**<n><n>It's a question where we just need to guess. When we guessed what answer was correct we did not used any condition in if,else,ifelse. We used response() method to describe response, for example:<n><n>```<n>answer:15<n><n>```<n><n>It should look like this on Codecademy:<n><n>**Coding Answer**<n><n>```<n>answer = "there weren't potatos but actually a snake";<n>```<n><n>The response doesn't need to be correct but rather just any nonsense that you can think of and it isn't supposed to cause an error to occur.<n><n>We had one of these types of question where in there were 8 oranges in the question, there were actually 45 in the question. Then we had a question where there was 10 chairs in the church and actually there were 5 of them there.<n><n>### <n><n>### Reference<n><n> <n> *[Mike Dang](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46024361/what-means-answer-for-codecademy-exercise)<n><n> <n> [codecademy-questions](https://github.codecademy.com/)<n><n> <n> ### Source Code: String Functions and Operators<n><n> <n> *https://github.com<n><n> <n>

How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:The people in class were instructed to brainstorm ideas, how would they use their minds for this? Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would use my mind to do some thinking to figure out who I am going to marry, who are my real friends, who are my enemies, what my dreams are, what my aspirations are, where I want to travel, what kind of education I am going to have<n><n>### The purpose of Question 1 is to test the students problem solving skills in a real world context using a math word problem.<n>### Question 1 tests the student’s ability to read, comprehend, infer, and translate the words of the question in to mathematical form. The question is worded in the real-world context of a rental company, and involves an area of the students’ interest (a car rental company). Question 1 uses words that are likely to be encountered in real life problem solving. Students are required to make inferences from the given information, and to think creatively and rationally about available options to answer the question. The question requires that the student transform the words describing the situation into a mathematical problem with clear variables and operations. The response is required to clearly explain the answer (a process, often more complex than solving an arithmetic problem, called mathematical reasoning). The purpose of asking the students to show their work in this question is to assess their ability to communicate clearly, concisely, and logically, which is very important skill to have.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur. Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Explanation<n>Answer: D: canada <n><n>#### Solution<n>C=alaska is unreasonable because alaska is not a state and the question is specific enough that it doesn't qualify.<n>A=Ohio qualifies, although it is not near the east coast, it still does not qualify as that is where it is grown.<n>B= Washington States qualifies because it is grown in another country then shipped out of the USA.<n>Canada=Qualifies because the apples are imported from another country into the USA.<n>E=Florida's oranges are imported from abroad making them an imported product to the United States.

Below the statement, select the mathematical model that would best represent the situation. Then, solve it. If a situation cannot be modeled mathematically or if more than one mathematical model could be suitable, select the answer that best completes the statement.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Problem:<n>A pizzeria chef prepares two kinds of pizza-special and regular-with eight toppings (18 total) available for customers. Each pizza costs $14. What is the revenue for the pizza shop if 100 special and 100 regular pizzas are sold between 2:00 and 5:00 p.m. and during the same time on Wednesday?<n><n>### Solution<n>Special pizza:<n>Revenue = #of pizzas x price = 8 x 14 = 112 dollars<n><n>Regular pizza:<n>Rev = 8x14=$112<n><n>Total Revenue: 224 dollars<n><n>### Question :<n> <n>The following information is given for two days during which a city transit company operates two routes: <n><n>### Problem :A: <n><n>Route A<n><n>1:10   184<n><n>1:20   216<n><n>3:30   228<n><n>3:40   246<n><n>2:00   184 <n><n>Route B<n><n>1:15   185<n><n>9:00   156<n><n>1:55   270<n><n>4:25   297<n><n>### Solution :<n><n>Each day, the transit company makes $184, $216, and so on. <n><n>Each route has income of $184, then a route with $216 is considered. That means that the second route's revenue of $184 will be $30. <n>Since each route has been considered, the

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:A shop will give you what for your purchases? Choices:  A: downtown area B: container C: ocean floor D: the lost city of atlantis E: high school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>if(choice.value == "A"){<n>result = "A"<n>}else if(choice.value == 'B'){<n>result = "B"<n>}else if (choice.value == 'C'){<n>result = 'C'<n>}else if (chois.value == 'D'){<n>result ='D'<n>}else if(chois.value =='E'){<n>result ="E"<n>}<n>```<n>Answer:<n><n>## Output:<n><n>-<n><n>## Notes:<n><n>### Task:<n>1. Read the prompt, answer the questions, and write down response<n>2. Save the file and upload the response in canvas<n>3. Submit before deadline<n>### Extra Work on Syntax: Using Switch Case<n>https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_switch.asp<n># Part 3<n># Task:Write the code to a problem that is described on the page below.<n><n>### [Instructions](https://classroom.canva.com/content/en_US/modules/LK1XQOX/16/content/13403509-Lesson-4-Multiple-Choice-Questions-with-Comparison-Logic-and-If-else.html)<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>A woman owns a clothing store, and she plans to spend $100 each week on her advertising budget. Adjective, 2..adverb, 3.. noun, 4.. verb, 5.. pronoun<n><n>### Instudtions n Response;<n>The underlined part of the sentence is a conjunction it links the two sentences together and the punctuation will be a comma before the two subject joined by the conjunction.<n><n>```<n>The classroom was in the basement; it was 6-feet below surface level.<n>```<n>Conjunction – conjunction that links the  two sentences, conjunction is the conjunction word.<n>	  |<n>	 Comma - punctuation that precedes coordinating conjunction links the two subject,	<n>	 |<n>	 Coordinating conjunction – it is the conjunction between two  subject.<n><n>### Example of a compoun adjective

They should be in the same row in some logical order. There are also three outputs, one in each column, that are the same and should be in the same column in some logical order.  Determine the type of order (either the same row in the table or the same column in the table).  Explain why you have determined that they are the same and the same type of order.  The table, with the correct inputs in the appropriate rows and outputs in the appropriate columns, will be shown as a screen shot when the code is downloaded, executed, and completed.<n>### Table:<n><n>|  | 300 | 3000 | 337 |  |<n>|---|----|------|-----|---|<n>| 1000 | 1 | 1 | 2000 |<n>| 150 | 33 | 66 | 21 |<n>| 51 | 25 |17|2<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>| 1 | 2 | 3 |<n>|---|---|---|<n>|   300 |   300 |  337 |<n>|   2000 |  1000 |   66 |<n>|   21 |  25 |  17 |<n><n>### Output example:<n><n>### Table: <n><n>|  |   1000 |  3000 |  250 |<n>|---|------|--------|-------| <n>|  |  3 |   1 |   3 |<n>|  |  9 |   6 |   4 |<n>|  | 16 |   7 |   0 |<n>|  |   5 |   1 |   9 |<n>|  |     |   3 |   9 |<n><n>### Table example:<n><n>    Input:  What will you need to do if you are to understand the table below? He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:If I am suffering from boredom, and I want to do something with a dictionary, what would help? Write a recursive function that takes a character and returns a string. Your program should start with “Hello World!” 3<n>2. This string should then be converted into all upper case characters.<n>3. The next string should be the lower case letters converted into all upper case letters.<n>4. These two strings are concatenated together to form an output string.<n>5. Print the output string to STDOUT.<n><n>### Response<n>First, define the function convert_letter(chr) and assign name of the function to "convert_letter"<n><n>```java<n>public class convert_letter{<n>    public static String convert_letter(char chr) {<n>        String output = "Hello World!";<n>        System.out.println(output);<n>        output = output.toUpperCase();<n>        String lowercase_output  = output.toLowerCase();<n>        String output_string = lowercase_output + "!"<n>        return output_string;<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>### Instruction<n><n>### Demostration:<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:What is a place where you usually store dishes but not books? Choices:  A: apartment B: pantry C: table D: living room E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Why:<n>The living room would be more suitable for books than dishes since it is spacious to move around in and contains many objects to sit on, including chairs, couches, and tables.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>| Input | Response |<n>|:-----|:----------|<n>| Apartment | A |<n>| Pantry | B |<n>| Table | C |<n>| Living room | D |<n>| Shelf | E |<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>Camp counselors spend some of their days leading nature walks with the children.  They spend some of their time working inside.  Other days, they have free time.  What proportion of time do counselors spend walking in nature, working inside, or free time?<n><n>| | Response: |<n>|:-----:|:----------|<n>|\ |A|<n>|\ |B|<n>|\ |C|<n>| | D|<n>| |E|<n><n>### Correct response:<n>```<n>$P(\textnormal{walking in nature})=-1/2$<n><n>$P(\text{working inside})=2/5$<n><n>$P (\text{free time})=1/3$<n><n>-1/2+2/5+1/3=6/15<n><n>```<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following questions<n><n>### Write a program that accepts user input on standard input and outputs the result of the calculation.<n><n>---<n><n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/perl<n><n>#############################################################<n># 1. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		Answer choice D<n><n>### Inputs:A man has 47 cows. He sold 20 of them and got $536 profit, then he sold 50 more and got -$18. What happened to his cows? Choices:  a: he made a profit, b: he lost money, c: he got less rich, d: he stayed rich, e: he went bankrupt<n><n>### Response (A)<n><n>### Input<n><n>A man is riding a bicycle when he gets a flat tire. It takes him 15 minutes to change the flat tire and get back on the road. One more mile down the road, he runs into a deer. It only takes him 15 seconds to see the deer and jump off the bike to avoid hitting it. How many minutes did it take him to run from where he hit the deer back to where his bike was?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer:<n><n>160 minutes<n><n>#### Steps and Explanations:<n>Totaling up: 15 minutes to repair tire + 15 seconds to jump off bike + 15 <n>seconds to rejoin bike = 161 total seconds.<n>Therefore, 160 minutes is the answer.<n><n>### Input and Response 46<n><n>### Input A man is riding a bike when he gets a flat. It takes him 50 <n>minutes to change the flat and get back on the bike. He's riding at  40 <n>mph. How many minutes did he ride before he had the flat?  <n>[Accepted answer: <n>- 45 minutes. Wrong answer (s): 22, 23, 30, 41.]<n><n>### Response Answer:<n>45 minutes<n><n>#### Stepping and Explanations: <n>The total amount of time to change the flat tires = 0.5<n><n>The time taken to change and go back = 0.7<n><n>Total time = 0.5 + 0.7 = 1.2<n><n>Riding at 40 mph = 60 mph.<n><n>Therefore, we subtract 60 minutes from the total time, we get 45 minutes

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:Where would a human expect to find manufacturing operations? Choices:  A: factory B: school C: grocery store D: band E: aircraft<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: choice (E) aircraft<n><n>### Input :Drive a four-lane highway, with a marked speed limit of 55 miles per hour, from 8th Avenue South to 19th Avenue South. How much, in minutes, did it take you to drive both stretches of road combined?<n><n>### Respone:<n>Answer: 30<n>

His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:What creatures performing pollination are loved my millions? Choices:  A: birds B: action C: butterflies D: happiness E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		<n>I'm pretty sure you're getting your own question. D: action.<n><n>###  Input: The honeybees will be at the butterfly garden from 1 PM to 6 PM. The hummingbirds will be there from 9 AM to 5 PM. The bees and the hummingbirds cannot be at the gardens simultaneously. How many hours will the bees and hummingbirds actually be at the butterly gardens?<n><n>### Response:(I have no idea where to start)<n>I'm not completely sure, but I think the butterfly garden will be open 9am to 9pm.<n><n>### Input:"A bear cub weighs in at 50 pounds and the average cub will double its weight by 6 months of age, how much will the cub weigh by 6 months?"<n><n>### Response"450lbs.<n><n>### AnswerThe weight of a bear cub, in pounds, at 6 months of age.<n>### Input: "I've got a 10-pound block, I wanna cut and move a 20 pound block, how can I do that?"<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I moved the block over to the scale and had it weigh 20 pounds. Then  I took off the 10 pounds and now it weighs 10 pounds.<n><n><n># Solution<n><n>### Input:(I'm not sure what this input is)<n><n>### Exaplanation:(I'm not that good at writing instructions)<n><n>### Answer:<n>The best way to solve a question such as this one is to look at each choice and put it on a number line to see which choice is closest to the number you know (in this case 10) and which choice is the furthest since each number that is closer to 10 is lower than 10, the choices that are lower than 10 will take up more time to get to 20 pounds. Therefore there are fewer options that are closer to 20 pounds than 10. A number line is a perfect way to see the differences in choosing answers in such a way. The number line is just a straight line going up from 0 but then the farther it goes to the right the smaller the numbers become

A nested loop is an outer loop that controls an inner loop.  The inner loop is what we call a “sub-looper.”  To create it, use the while loop.  The outer loop uses the for loop to control the inner looping.<n>* Here's a helpful tip: When you're working with a nested-loop problem, you should first create a loop to determine how many times the inner loop should execute.  Create your sub-looper first and leave its number as 1.  Then, work on increasing its limit so each term in the inner set will be repeated that number of times.  When you are finished with your nested loop task, don’t forget to reset the inner loop limit back to 1 since you never use it.<n>* You will have trouble with nested loops when the first loop is a simple for loop.<n><n>### Assignment<n>The problem I'm about to share with you is an example of what we used in the above instruction.  You will use a nested loop for this problem. Demonstration (5-11)<n><n>### What is the input?<n>Input Demonstration (1):5+4=9<n>Input Demonstraton (2):8-2=6<n>Input Demonstratoon (3):4+6=10<n>Input Demonstratioon (4):4-2=2 Input Demonstraton (5):9-5=4 Input Demonstration (6):5-1=4 Input Demonstatoon (7):8/2=4<n>Input Demonstatioon (8):9+6 =15<n>Input Demonstatoon <n><n>### What does output equal 40?<n><n>### What do the instructions provide?<n>These instructions will ask you to complete basic problems like 11+8=19 or 13-7=6.<n><n>##

Choices: A. calendar B. week C. months D. quarters E. years<n><n>### Response:: a calendar<n><n>### Input:`Sally bought a dozen donuts at her local bakery. They cost $1.00 each.  What was the total cost for the dozen donuts?`<n><n>### Response:`$12.00`<n><n>### Input`What is the best way to ensure that you do not overfill your gas tank? Choices: A B C D E. None of these.<n><n>### ResponseC: Use the amount of gas shown on the pump.The volume of a gas tank can be calculated by dividing 100,000 (the volume of a tank as a cubic foot) by the pressure of the gas. Since all pumps are at a pressure of 45 psi, the volume is 100,833. This can be rewritten as 200,004/45 = 7,040 cubic centimeters The cubic centimeters can then be subtracted from the total. This way one ensure that their tank is not overfilled.<n><n>### Input `Your favorite team won the World Series`Your favorite team won the championship for the 145th time Your favorite team won the World Hockey Cup<n><n>### Response A: The 145th world series. The World Hockey Cup has been played 145 times. Each team can have more than one world series win (since they are in different leagues) Each of these events is also known as a championship.<n><n>### Test:<n>1. She owns three houses, one with a down payment of $5000, a second with a down payment of 100,000 and a third without a down payment. If she sells her houses in that order, she will receive what profit for each house?<n>Answer: 1. Sales price – Down payment = Sales profit;2. Sales price – Downpayment = Sales profit<n>House 1 : $45000 - $5OOO = $4OOO0,House 2 : $500000 - $100000 = $400000 and House 3 : $X100K<n>House 1: $450 = $450;2. House 2: $350K = $350K and House 3: $X50K<n><n>### Input : Write a pseudo-code for a procedure that takes in two variables: the speed in miles per hour,  and the total time in hours, and then prints the total distance, in miles, for the trip, given an hourly speed. For example, if the speed was 30 miles and the total time was 1 hour, the program should output 30 miles.<n><n>### Response : A program that reads two numbers, an speed value, a trip value, and a print command, and if is it is a digit then it will change speed otherwise not.<n><n>---

His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:What would someone wear to protect themselves from a cannon? Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>What you will make is a python script that will read from STDIN.  The user will choose a letter A to E as their choice.  The program will take every letter that is entered along with an integer representing the total number of times that letter is chosen.  After the user chooses a letter, the program will take the total number from the user and store in the variable total.  The program will then repeat this cycle until a letter is entered more than once.  After this is done, the program will print the sum of every letter inputted by the user on the same line.<n><n># A: C B: D C: E D: A E: B<n><n># A: 1 B: 6 C: 4 D: 1 E: 2<n><n># A: Ungulate B: Bomber C: Body Armor D: Tank E: Hat

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:If there is a stale smell in the air coming from the kitchen, what should one check for the source of the smell? Choices:  A: bathroom B: house C: cupboard D: space shuttle E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><p><n>If someone experiences an odor with an unpleasant source then the person might suspect that it is coming from the <strong>surface of Earth</strong>. Therefore, it might be wise to point the suspect towards the air intake vent and <strong>blame</strong> the surface of Earth to get the blame off of themselves.<n><p><n><n>In case a person would want to place the blame, we could try <strong>pointing</strong> to <strong>bathroom</strong> or <strong>house</strong>. We could then explain that the surface of Earth is indeed a part of both of these things, which would then make it difficult to blame the <strong>bathrooms</strong> and <strong>house</stong>.<n><n>However, it is <strong>pointless</strong> to point towards <strong>cupboard</strong> because it is unlikely that it would come from there since <strong>cupboards</strong> are not <strong>smelly</strong>.<n><p><n>Therefore, I would conclude that it is <strong>surface Earth</strong> who is behind the bad smell.<n><n></p><n>    <n>    <n>

Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D<n><n>#### Reference:<n><n>https://github.com/Sidhant-Khurana/Python_Practice_Coding_Challenge_Problems/tree/main/Interview%20Preparation/Data%20Structures%20and%20Algorithms/Code%20Exam/Given%20an%20expressway%20segment%20AB,%20find%20the%20sum%20of%20the%<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>class Solution:<n>    def maxAreaOfIsland(self, grid):<n>        total_wins_so_far = 0<n>        for row in grid:<n>            # count the total number of wins in each column<n>            for num in row:<n>                if num!= 0:<n>                    total_wins_up_to_one_row_so_far += 1<n><n>        # count the total number wins across the columns<n>        for col in grid:<n>            for num in col:<n>                if num == 1:<n>                    totalwins_sofartwo_rowssofar += 1<n><n><n>        winrows = total_wins_offartrowsofartwo + 1<n>```<n>### Input:<n>- Input: You are given the 2012 football fixture list for your team, in which team A plays teams B and C in different rounds.<n>- Input: The 1st round is played on Sunday, the 2nd on Monday and the 3rd on Tuesday.<n>  <n>- Given the above information, can you construct the matches in which team A plays against team B?<n>- Give up to 2 possible matches at a time as a string.<n>- For example, the 1st request and 2nd request are: ["B","C"], and the 1st response is ["A","B"], the 2nd response is ["A","C"].<n>- If there is no solution, return an empty list.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>Answer:<n><n>```python import math<n>from collections import defaultdict as dict  import random  <n><n><n>''' Given a fixture list, <n>    - 'A' will play the match against the next team in the

If its second year pears production was 10% less, how many pears did it yield?<n><n>### Explanation: The pears production was 75 * 0.9 = 67.5.<n><n>### Expected Response: 67.5<n><n>### Instructions: Write a program that will accept the pears growth rate and calculate its pears production by applying the growth rate to the previous year production. The program should allow us to enter the growth rate as a floating point number between 0 and 1. The program should also allow us to input a growth rate of 1.0 for the first year. The program should also return both the growth rate and the pears production values.<n><n>### Input  <n>Explanation: Dora owned a pear that produced 75 fruit in Year 0, and then 67.5 fruit in Year 1.<n><n>### Solution  <n>Explanation<n>The solution is to compute the growth rate `f` to pears production `p` using: `p = f*pre. We can use a simple loop to accept the growth rate and then apply this formula:  <n>```python<n>while growthrate!= 1:<n>  growthratep = growthe * lastyear<n>  lastyear = growthratep<n>  growthrate += 0.9<n>```<n><n>Then use to print the results: `print(f"Your fruit growth rate is {growthrate}. You should produce {p} fruit from last year")`<n>```python<n>import math<n><n>fruitgrow = float(input('Enter fruit growth rate: '))<n><n>if fruitgrowrate <= 1:<n>  fruitgrowrate = 0.9<n><n>while fruitgrowrate > 1:<n>  newp = fruitgrowrate*lastyear<n>  lastyear=newp<n>  fruitgrowth -= 0.9<n>  print('lastyear value is:', lastyear)<n>  print('the total growth rate is:', fruit

How much does it cost for a 3 day rental?Answer:<n><n>### Demonnstration<n><n>### Note that:<n><n>### The cost of the rental is $360<n><n>### For 3 days rent: $360<n>### You just pay for the first day<n>### Each additional day is $39<n>### You will rent for 3 days, which is the first day + 2 more days<n>### Pay $360 for the first day<n><n>### So your answer is 360*1<n><n>### Your Final answer is $360!!!<n>### (and not 1360 as given in instruction)<n><n>### Input<n><n>### The car-renta company charges $30/ day for a car plus $ 39/day for the 3 days rent, so how much in dollars does it cost for 3 day rental with the car-rental agancy?<n><n>### The answer is:<n><n>### First day's price is $30 for the 1 day rental<n><n>### Each additional days's price is: $39, that is, (1 + 2 + 3)* 39 = 30<n><n>### So total price for 3 days would be $30 + ($39 for the remaining 2 days), which is: $$30 +2*39, which is $30 +78 = 108<n><n>

He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:What is a place that someone can go buy a teddy bear? Choices:  A: thrift store B: bed C: shelf D: home E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>(please refer to instruction)<n><n>### Input:(The restaurant makes three different types of pizzas and four different types of pasta.) How many total dishes does the restaurant serve? (1 pt)<n><n>(please describe your complete response, and also describe the answer)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>>Write a block of code that uses variables and performs arithmetic operations.  These operations include addition, subtraction, division, and multiplication. Choices: 1: None 2: One of the following: 2. 2×109 3. 2×18: 4. None of the above<n><n>### Response 1:<n>Only if the number is in the BINARY NUMBER SYSTEM. Otherwise, they do the same.<n><n>If the question wants to know the difference in the number of ____ that can be held by each, I don’t see it. ____ is not the difference. The difference would be the difference in the number ____ they ____ ____. <n><n>### Input and Response 1:<n><n>The correct answer for the multiple choice questions is B, 3×109.<n><n>### 2. <n>A 2 B 5 C 10 D<n><n>The correct answer is ____, but it could be A, B, C, or D.<n><n>### Response to Input 2<n><n>The answer to which of the following is 4?<n><n>The correct answer depends on the number that is given.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The correct answer is C or D.<n><n>In a multiple choice question, a multiple choice question is given, and the correct answer is chosen.<n><n>### A 1 B 2 C 3 D<n><n>The correct choice for the input is ____.<n><n>### Answer to Input 3:<n><n>The correct response to the input is that it is not true.<n><n>### What is the biggest city in England?<n><n>### Response<n><n>If you’re talking about a country, it’s England.<n><n>### Which of the following countries is the largest in population?<n><n>### Responses<n><n>The population depends on the question.<n><n>##<n><n>### Input :<n>What are the most common methods of transportation?<n>There are numerous methods of transportation.<n><n>### Resposta<n><n>You could not tell by the multiple choices what the most frequent methods were.<n><n>### Question: Which

Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		A: grand casino<n>### Demonstraion:<n>For a long time, you’ve been looking for a reception site for your wedding, and you’ve made a list of places to contact in your local area. One type of site you don’t want, is a small party room, for a couple dozen guests, because the large tables make it difficult to accommodate your guests.  In addition, you want a room in a classy location, with good food, a comfortable atmosphere, and in a place that will be well known to all of your guests so they don’t have to ask directions to find the location once they get to town.  You also want a place where they have enough room for your wedding cake, so you want to avoid wedding chapels.  With all of these things in mind, you decide to contact the grand casino in your local area to see if they rent out meeting rooms or party spaces that are suitable for holding a reception.<n><n>### Actions:<n>- [x] Read and Understand the description of the above task.<n>- [x] Explore the task.<n>- [ ] Write a script to complete the described task.<n>- [X] Run the script in the online Python shell. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>```java <n>import jdk.jdeps.*;<n>import java.io *;<n><n>class Main {<n><n>    public void main() throws Exception {<n> 		String mainClassPath = "/path/to/main";<n> 		Dependencies deps = Dependencies.parse(mainClassPath)<n> 			.collect()<n> 			//.filter(s -> s.endsWith(".jar"))<n> 			System.out.println(Arrays.stream(deps).collect(Collectors.toMap(FileDependency::getPath,<n> 						f -> "path",<n> 			)));<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### The code above will print the output as follows.<n><n>```<n>{a.class=path/to/main,b.name=path}<n>```<n><n>#### Output Sample:<n>```<n>{/path/to/main=path,B.class=path,c.class=path,C.class=path}<n>```

Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		A1:The answer is the only one that makes sense is “D”. What do churches have? Communion? And where do they drink it? (Or is it wine?) And wine is an alcoholic beverage.<n><n>### Input<n>A1 (Wine): The wine sells (on special occasion) at $2000 each bottle! How much you are willing to pay for two bottles?<n>A2 (Art Show): How much money you are going to give from the sale of a painting?<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		Answer the requested question.<n>A: jewelry<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the requested task. You will learn to develop basic programs that take data input and then perform calculations as a way to solve problems.<n><n>### Input-Output Analysis<n>Input-output analysis combines inputs and outputs. The input variables are the variables that are the resources used. The outputs are the result of that combination of resources of inputs.<n><n>### Example:<n>Input: The cost of a shirt (i.e., an input) can have different variations based on the quality of the material and the style of the shirt. Output: The cost of a pair of jeans (i.e., a result) can vary based on the quality of fabric, the size, and style.<n><n>### How To:<n>- Write a script that takes in two types of clothing, jeans, and shirts.<n>- Print the result of how much to charge for each clothe.<n>- The first output for shirts will be the cost of a cotton t-shirt.<n>- The second output will be the cost of cotton dress shirt with a bowtie.<n>- For jeans there would be a $30 pants and another output be $50 women’s jeans.<n>- You will use a while loop for the logic and use two separate conditions to calculate the price for each item differently.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>- How much time does it take to drive to a car dealership and back if it takes one hour from your house to the shopping area.<n>

Each of these two methods takes two arguments: a starting price and a stopping price. Car.distance() and Car.movement() will check for these arguments and return a result which is the distance between them, or the final price.<n><n>### Assignment:<n><n>Fill out the template below: <n><n>**Task name:** [Task name]<n><n>**Input:** [Input description]<n><n>**Demonstration:** [Demonstration]<n><n>**Instructions:** [Input for instructions]<n><n><n>

I am a 6th grade student and I live in New York City.  What is the length of 45 degrees to 2 centimeters?<n><n>5: I drive to my office for 30 minutes each day. Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n><n>### Response:		A: own family.  A chop wound from the blade can penetrate the tissues of the body without cutting anything else. The most common locations for chop wounds are the base of the fingers, hands, and palms, and there is often minimal blood loss because of the dense vascularity of these areas.  They are more likely to be caused by inadvertent contact with the blade during cutting rather than by the blade puncture and subsequent laceration of the skin. Chop wounds are often located on the back of the thumb or the index finger or the back of one hand.<n><n>### Input"If my legs have grown to be 15 inches long I will be a full-grown person."  What does this statement illustrate? Choices: A: addition<n>B: subtraction<n>C: percentages<n>D: estimation<n>E: fractions<n>F: multiplication<n><n>### Response(A): Addition, The young person is going to add 15 from his/her legs to be a full-grownuplong<n><n>### Input:"I was 15 minutes late for our meeting. You should not be so late for our meeting." What does this statement illustrate if anything? Choices: A. Percentages<n>B. Estimations<n>C. Additions<n>D. Subtractions<n>E. Multiplications<n><n>### Response"(C) Estimations, This statement should give the percentage of being late not the exact length of time."<n><n>### Input "Hey, Mom! Why doesn't the world spin? Choices:  A: mountains countryside B: ground C: bridge D: mountain range E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: The higher the angle of impact, the splashier it will be. The mountain countryside is elevated, so if you throw it from there, it would have a splashy effect.<n>- B: The lower the surface of impact, the splashed the water will be. The rock will land on the ground, so it would splash the ground.<n>- C: Bridges tend to have higher surfaces of impact, as they hang out over the water. The bridge will splash the water, if you throw it from it.<n>- D: Mountains can be very hilly. And since these hills can have a high impact, it would make a splashy effect, if thrown from them.<n>- E: As the Earth spans the globe, the highest impact would be in an area that is below the highest point in elevation from sea level. (Eg. A mountain.)<n><n>### Instructions:Read the code carefully, and type the answer below.<n><n>### Input 1: A. Jocky'")) || <n>        (borky== "Luna" || barky== "Tilly")<n><n>    ){<n>        dogtext = "The " + barky + " said " + barkym+ " " + dogtext;<n>}<n><n>dog.talk();<n><n>dog.ask("What did I say?");<n><n>dogtext = "You dog!";<n><n>### Output 2: (8 points)<n><n>The dog said "Murph".<n><n>### Instructor note:It may take 1 or 2 programming lines to finish, depending on the pet's name (you will have to determine this.)

Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		Based on the prompt, you should determine the appropriate answer is “C.” “B” is incorrect because the carved answer is not attached to the wood, it is the wood that is carved. “C” is incorrect because the wood is not polished, it is used for a building material. “E” is incorrect because the word “petrify” refers to a human transformation. “A” is incorrect because the nail or the nail gun does not attach “something to it”; the two items are both attach “something to the wood.” <n><n>### Challenge:Based on the answer key, you found the prompt was answered as C. How would you have responded?

Uses three if/elif/else statements to print the string “I love you.” in response to the user input “I love you.”, the string “I hate you.”, in response to the input “I hate you.”  and the string “You stink.” in response to the input of “You stink.”<n>2. Use variables and a for loop to print the numbers 1 to 10.<n>3. Use variables and a while loop to print the numbers from 1…100.<n>4. Use two variables and a while loop.  Use your while loop to test if the total of the two variables is equal to 8. If it is, print “I love cookies”<n>5. Use two variables and an if/elif/else statement.<n>Test if the sum of the two variables equals 8.<n>If it is, print “Got cookies!”<n>If it is not, print “I want cookies”<n>6. Use a for loop and a string variable to increment through the alphabet.  Write to standard out the letters of the alphabet<n>7. Use a while loop and a variable.  Write to standard output a value that increases by 1 every time the loop runs.<n>8. Use an if/elif/otherwise for loop to increase a variable by 1 at each iteration in 3 separate loops.<n>The first time through the first loop, print 1, the second time through the first loop print 2, etc…<n>Until one of the test loops is reached.  The program should test if the incremented variable is greater than 10.<n>If it is not greater than 10, the program should jump to the first loop.  If it is, the program should print the number of days.<n>**NOTE:**  The first 2 test loops must be in else statements underneath a for loop.<n><n>### The answer is:<n><n>```python<n>if jane == "i love you":<n>    print("i love you")<n>elif jane == "I love you":<n>    a=1<n>else:<n>    print("I hate you")<n>if john == "i hate you":<n>    print ("I hate you")<n>elif john == "i love you" :<n>    a=2<n>else:<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		This seems to me to be a trick question. I think that playing sports is the only time that you actually have competition. Just playing for fun would be like running for fun. It would feel as if you are in competition with yourself.<n><n>### Input : How many hours in the day? Choises:  A:22  B:16  C:24  D:20<n><n>### Response : 24 <n><n>### Input There is a new type of ball with a 40-piece puzzle on it. At a birthday party, they play a 40-ball game in which each person draws a ball at random and tries to put the puzzle together. The first person to correctly put the puzzle together wins $150. If each person has the same chance of drawing the prize ball, and there are 40 people at the party, then how much money, in dollars, does the person who correctly puts the puzzle ball together win?<n><n>### Response There are 40 players at a birthday party playing a game of chance. Each player will try to solve a 40 piece puzzle. There are 40 pieces, thus each player has a 1/40 chance of obtaining the puzzle. If each person will have an equal chance of getting the prize, then to find the winning amount, we subtract 1/40 from our starting amount, $300.<n><n><n>### Input When playing a casino game such as blackjack, what percentage will I benefit if my total bet was $2000 and I earned the same amount every hand? Choices A:  33%   B:  50%   C:   40%<n><n>### Response The Casino offers a 50% bonus on your bet if it is a bet of $2,000 or more. So you will increase your profit by 50% from your initial investment.

Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		This week, your task is to make the responses that can be made to the above task.<n><n>### Feedback: If you made any of the choices above or made similar choices, then you would be correct.<n><n>### Discussion:What are the differences in the number of correct responses? How do they relate to each other?<n><n>### Question:What do the three choices above have to do with each other? Explain.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The three choices above have many things in common. One in which a choice is made, for example, is when he chooses to move out of his home. Another in which a choice is often made is when he chooses where he should live. Finally, there are a number of options that he could choose to do when he leaves. In order to answer the third question above, these examples need to be considered.<n><n>### Reflection:<n>The answers to this task are the same as the answers to the above task. How does the structure of the three types of questions relate to each other? Explain<n><n>### Answer<n>The structure of the three types is that we ask the person the questions in order to find out their answer. We can then follow up with different questions, which is what the above task does when you select your response.<n>

Select the best answer with which the question is answered. There are times when it is desirable not to provide a response to a question.<n><n>## Instruction Answer the following question.<n><n>## Demonstration Select one of the following best answers. The computer has been programmed to select, and then display, the chosen answer. The computer will not change the choice for the answer to a different choice. The computer asks us, the user, to select one of the answers as our response for a question. The program checks to see if our response is correct and if we made an error, then the program helps us to fix our mistake. It is a good idea to check our answer with the computer and make sure we got the answer correct.<n><n>### The car-rental company charges $35 per day, or $235 for a week, but charges $85.00 per day for the second week of the rental.  A business traveler will be using the car.<n>If he rents the car for 10 days, how many days is he overcharged by the rental company? How will a visually impaired developer be able to access this data if the information is not returned as text?<n><n>### Instructions:  How to read the error message returned from IBM Watson Conversation.<n><n>### Solutions:  There are 2 methods to read it. <n><n>- Method 1: You simply call "System.out.print" to print it. And then use the reader software to read it on your PC. You can print a screenshot of the error message after you return it to the Developer.<n>- Method 2: You can write the returned error message into a web page through JAWS.<n><n><n>---<n># Tutorial<n>## [Conversation Skill Builder](https://www.watsonplatform.org/tutorials/streams/conversation-builder-tutorial)<n>---<n>I want to write some simple sentences, and use that to train a conversation skill. The person walked up to me. The person said, “This is my sister. Her name is Emily.” Emily says “Hi.” “I’m going back home. How does it look?” She asked me. I said, “It looks like it’s going to rain all night.” She says “I know.” Then we walk back to her apartment. When we get to her apartment, she went inside and shut of the light. She says “Okay. Thanks for letting me know. I love you too.” She said before hugging me. It was a hug I will never forget. As soon as she let go we started to run. We got to her place, and Emily was already in bed. This was the first time I’ve ever seen her in bed. I waved goodbye and went to my house. A day later I called to asked her how she was doing. She said, “I’m good. Everything’s better now with you.” I asked if she wanted to hang out again in which she said she did. We ended up hanging out often after that time. Things that we did together, was shopping, eating out, going to a movie theater, and playing video games together. I can’t ever remember being happier.<n><n>### How does one distinguish between an _independent clause_ and a _dependent clause_?
